page.title: 04NW.SHERBORNE:HEDGEROWS
page.content: Although a number of the field hedges have disappeared in recent years, to create larger fields to suit changing farming methods, hedges still form an integral part of the {landscape.}They usually contain a wide {variety of plants}both in the hedge itself and in the verge either side. They are an important{habitat}for wild-life. The hedges at the roadside are usually growing above a grassy bank which may conceal a low stone wall. In the summer months these banks become very{overgrown}with cow-parsley making the minor roads appear even narrower so that a car may brush against growth from both sides of the road. Periodically the hedges are{trimmed}by a machine attached to a tractor. Attempts are made to preserve {wild-flowers}growing in the verges.
